B00003JRCQ|5.0|\\"Good company is always worth seeking.\\"<br /><br />\\"My idea of good company is the fellowship of clever, well informed people, who have a great deal of conversation and a liberality of ideas.  That is what I call good company.\\"<br /><br />\\"That is not good company.  That is . . .\\"  (If you want to know the rest of the line, then rent the movie).<br /><br />During her lifetime Jane Austen published her novels anonymously - a choice common for female authors of that time.  One of my favorite college professors had a sentence on a piece of paper on his office door.  It said, \\"I'd rather be reading Jane Austen.\\"  In the early 1800s, before psychology was a science, Jane Austen, an unmarried young woman, had the audacity to publish her thoughts on the workings of the inner mind.<br /><br />This is an excellent movie adaptation of Austen's final novel, a novel she wrote when her health was failing and she probably knew she had little time left to express what she had to say.  Reading the cast list for this movie is a \\"Who's who\\" of great actors:  Amanda Root, Ciaran Hinds, Corin Redgrave, Sophie Thompson, etc.  The acting is terrific.  There are certain movies that are so good that I don't wish to comment too much on the movie itself because it is not improved by my commentary.  Other movies in that category include Emma Thompson's Sense & Sensibility (to which Ms. Thompson added many of her own sensibilities to the screenplay).<br /><br />Austen's characters are often caught up in an internal dialogue, constantly re-evaluating the decisions of the past.  In Austen's era, these thoughts were made more desperate and consequential because romantic love could only be found in one other person.  Her characters are constantly jockeying to gain power, stature, & wealth through social, exclusivity contracts.  For Austen's characters, the one person is usually separated by distance, time, or rules of society.  Austen comments on how the mind seems to concentrate on the imprinted loves of the past (See Spielberg's \\"A.I.\\").  Her heroines tend to think there was a person in their past whose character so well matched their own, that to be reunited would bring some fulfilment.  And in her novels, often the two are combined in the end, defying the odds and rewarding their moral behavior and steadfastness.  The reader can see that the two are not just imprinted on each other;  rather, there are many good reasons why their chemistry works well.<br /><br />\\"Captain Wentworth . . . You have an extraodinary ability to discompose my friend sir.\\"<br /><br />This is true.  The book is titled \\"Persuasion\\".  It is not titled \\"Control\\".  The protagonists in the movie argue regularly with the intent to be persuasive, not to be controlling - and that is an essential distinction.<br /><br />\\"Perhaps you have not been in Bath long enough to learn to enjoy these parties they give.\\"<br /><br />\\"They mean nothing to me.  Those who hold them believe the theatre to be beneath their dignity, but I am no card player.\\"<br /><br />\\"No.  You never were, were you?\\"<br /><br />Jane Austen, as a young woman was a genius ahead of her time, and in some ways is still ahead of our time.  Great authors and artists find a way to speak to their generation in a way that both respects the status quo, yet somehow uses metaphor or narrative to look on the status quo's priorities from a new perspective.  For example, Willa Cather's \\"My Antonia\\" may be one of the first great works of lesbian literature (although most people would probably disagree with me).  That book certainly is not written from an ordinary male \\"voice\\", even if the narrator is male.  Similarly, Jane Austen questioned every social construct around her and tried to illustrate the conflicts that the social systems created against the natural, moral drives of the human psyche.  Her debate has fascinated us for hundreds of years.<br /><br />The movie is not about \\"old, boring people who lived hundreds of years ago.\\"  Likeall her novels, this movie is robust and a worthwhile social discourse today.<br /><br />Please comment, express feedback, or suggest related works.comment, express feedback, or suggest related works.

B00005JOQS|3.0|The reason to bring back Superman to film is because the movie technology is there to realize the potential of what special effects can do to the character in a live action movie.  That is the reason why George Lucas decided to do the next trilogy to his STAR WARS saga. The technology was there to bring his vision(s) to the screen.  SUPERMAN RETURNS misses the opportunity to realize what can be done with Superman with modern movie CGI.  What little they did in SUPERMAN RETURNS is great, but it wasn't enough.  The movie is an astounding 2 hrs and 37 minutes, but for some reason it seems like a hollow and empty shell of a movie. This reviewer remembers coming out psyched from the Spider-Man films and BATMAN BEGINS, but dissapointed cominig out of this film.  It has been touted by its creators that this new version is to pay homage to the Richard Donner films (Superman I and Superman II.--Actually, everyone is forgetting that Richard Lester is the credited director of Superman II.). One of the first problems facing this film is again, the Lex Luthor character.  Kevin Spacey chews up the scenery and is evil beyond comprehension.  However, we don't know why he is this way.  In SPIDER-MAN and SPIDER-MAN 2  (Spider-Man definitely has a better rouge's gallery than Superman), the villains are fully realized and fleshed out. In all the Superman films, Lex Luthor is evil with no thought behind the character except that he is evil and he is Superman's archenemy. After four films (including this one), it has become old and tiresome. In, SUPERMAN RETURNS, his obsession with land and real estate is brought over from the first two films as a plot motivation.  It is hilarious in a way, but also trite and annoying. In the first film he wanted California, in the second film he wanted Australia. This time, he wants to create his own continent in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean by using Kryptonian technology stolen from Superman's Fortress of Solitude. Note: If the creators wanted this to be \\"almost\\" a continuation of the first two movies, why not bring back the \\"Otis\\" and \\"Miss Teschmacher\\" characters. The next problem of the film is the relationship of the support characters. Brandon Routh does a great job as Clark Kent and Superman, but has little to do or say.  In the first movie and in the comic books themselves, part of the charm was the Clark Kent and Lois Lane relationship, which is badly absent in this movie.  Kate Bosworth does a fine job as Lois, but spends the whole movie ignoring or dissin' Clark and the two are rarely seen together interacting even as co-workers, collaborators, or old friends. He comes back after 5 years, and all Lois can say is \\"Oh! Hi, Clark! Welcome Back!\\" Her attitude towards Superman is even worse. The next problem is the support characters. Jimmy Olsen's total admiration society attitude for Clark Kent was not funny and is unwatchable. Jimmy Olsen should be played straight and mature instead of adolescent.  Jackie Cooper was a great Perry White and had more to say in the first two Superman movies. Frank Langella has no presence in this film whatsoever. Lastly the next problem is the character in Lois Lane's son.  Supposedly it is revealed that this son is a result of Superman's/Clark's and Lois' consummation at the Fortress of Solitude when Superman briefly gave up is powers (from Superman II). The creators have painted themselves in a corner by creating this character at least for the purposes of the proposed sequels. In the film, the character is pretty much a distraction and an annoyance with no relevance to the story or to the Superman mythos. Lastly (a nitpicking flaw) Superman claims he hears everything.  Why couldn't he hear Lex Luthor when Luthor was at his Fortress of Solitude or when he was planning his plot to create a continent out of Kryptonian crystals and Kryptonite? Overall, a 200 million dud-buster that was over-hyped and basically had nothing to say and nothing to show.  The creator's shouldhave started off fresh like what the creators did with the Batman franchise in BATMAN BEGINS. It's as if Bryan Singer helmed SUPERMAN RETURNS to purposely sabotage it so that he knew it wouldn't out perform his own X-Men franchise. If this movie was a homage to the Donner vision, why didn't they just get Richard Donner to direct the film? It's obvious he is still an able director and can direct sequels (i.e. his LETHAL WEAPON series!).have started off fresh like what the creators did with the Batman franchise in BATMAN BEGINS. 0446691437|3.0|This book started out really good. The first section on resistance is excellent, but then you start to get a feel for just how weird and negative this guy really is. From the personal anecdotes he gives involving his past, you'd think this guy was a complete loser. He didn't get anything published until his mid-forties, and says he was 'starving' until then. He talks about how he lived in a trailer crammed with garbage and that his neighbor (who slept in a trailer named 'moby dick') would teach him 'the evils of the marketplace'. He also worked in an oilfield and lived with a bunch of 'transient geeks' as he calls them, one of whom gave him yoga lessons at night. Not to mention he goes golfing with some scottish guy named 'the Hawk', worships his muse like a god, and believes in Zeus. He also says his prayer 'loud & in earnest' (mental image of him acting it out like a play at his desk). All in all, I'd say this guy is a bonafide fruitcake.  <br /> <br />Another thing is that I kept finding this guy contradicting himself on whether or not a professional should love his work. One minute he's saying that you have to truly love your work, the next that you should be completely detatched from it, and 'let the divines do their work'. He talks about the person as a vessel through which angels work their magic and bring already-realized pieces of art (in the heavens, that is) down here into our world for us all to enjoy. Going by that, he's saying that no work is really original, that it's all already laid out in heaven - we're just the lowly servants bringing it into reality. While I agree with this somewhat, it seems like he's discrediting the whole creative process entirely by saying that he just lets spirits work through him. I feel that there's a whole lot more to it than that, and I hope others do too.  <br /> <br />He also believes that writers who write for a target audience, and not for themselves, are 'hacks'. If you've read Stephen King's 'On Writing' or Dean Koontz's book, you'll realize that these two popular authors treat it like a profession, and therefore are 'hacks' in Pressfield's eyes. I don't agree with this...you can still write for an audience and throw in your own brand of originality, and you can keep food on the table and support a family. This guy believes in staying 'hardcore' and starving if need-be (and he ruined his marriage, as he states so matter-of-factly early on in the book).  <br />I also don't appreciate his apparent disdain for anyone who doesn't commit themselves fully to being an author, whom he calls 'amateurs'. I don't believe that someone who writes just as seriously on weekends and has a steady week job in a different avenue of creativity is simply 'amateur'. Actually, early on in the book he states that real professionals only take on tasks that are new to them, and never repeat things they've done before (no longer challenging). Is it really 'amateur' to take on different avenues of creativity, like sculpting, art, film, comics, game design, etc., as well as writing? This guy seems to believe only the hardcore purists are the real deal. Everyone else is just on the wrong path.  <br /> <br />Sigh. This book came highly recommended to me, and I was hoping it would have more than just a chapter's worth of genuine, sound advice. But in all honesty, this guy really isn't a great role model. If you're not bothered by being a 'starving artist' like this guy apparently was through most of his life, then maybe you'll identify with the later chapters. I, however, was a little ticked at his cynical, negative attitude and a little weirded out by all his greek god fantasies and pseudo-religious mumbo jumbo (and this guy actually claims he's a christian in the first chapter - a christian who prays to Zeus's daughter, and holds the Invocation of the Muse from Homer's Odyssey as his deepest prayer? Riiight).

Even with more than three hours of screen time, every director who has tried to tell the story has been forced to use the amateur, Lucasian technique of showing, not telling, and that has one effect on viewers -- it puts us to SLEEP.  <br /> <br />Seriously. I fell asleep twice watching this mess of a movie before I was able to make it through the entire thing. <br /> <br />And for the uninitiated, cramming in as many possible references to Bene Gesserits, Mentats and Kwisatz Haderachs doesn't make the story seem appealing -- it just makes it seem like it was written by a lunatic with a penchant for ridiculous-sounding names and long-winded plots. <br /> <br />So what's there to like about this movie? The decision to use \\"Weirding Modules\\" was a bizarre one, but actually pans out later in the movie as the battle scenes bring some excitement to the screen. And if you like the series, despite its many flaws, the movie is an interesting retelling of the Dune story. If you're a fan of Dune this is probably worth picking up. If you're not, watching this movie means you're guaranteed to be confused.

B00005OWEG|5.0|Director:  Francis Ford Coppola <br />Cast:  Martin Sheen, Marlon Brando, Robert Duvall, Frederic Forrest, Sam Bottoms, Laurence Fishburne, Albert Hall, Harrison Ford, Dennis Hopper. <br />Running Time:  202 minutes <br />Rated R for Rated R for disturbing violent images, language, nudity, sexual content and some drug use. <br /> <br />We hear \\"Apocalypse Now\\" before we see it. The low 'whup-whup-whup' of a helicopter's propellers is audible over a black screen, which slowly reveals a lush, exotic forest. The camera holds a long shot on this peaceful scene before the forest explodes into a fiery inferno as the napalm attack is launched. On the soundtrack, Jim Morrison tells us that \\"This is the end\\" and we are sucked instantly into the mad, horrible, wonderful world of \\"Apocalypse Now\\".  The 1979 film is Francis Ford Coppola's loose adaptation of Joseph Conrad's 'Heart of Darkness', scripted by John Milius, and updated to take place in the Vietnam War. The story concerns an American soldier named Willard (Martin Sheen) who is living a drunken, tortured existence in a Saigon hotel room while waiting for his next mission. Soon he is called into action (\\"I wanted a mission, and for my sins they gave me one\\") and given the task of assassinating a decorated Colonel who has gone AWOL. Colonel Kurtz (Marlon Brando) is in fact living as a kind of god to a local tribe on a compound deep in the Jungle. Willard must travel upriver and \\"terminate - with extreme prejudice\\". <br /> <br />Well that's one story anyway. The other, more incredible tale surrounding \\"Apocalypse Now\\" is how this film got made. There's the story of a six-week shoot that lasted for sixteen months. How Harvey Keitel was cast in the role of Willard and replaced after two weeks by Martin Sheen, who promptly had a breakdown (captured on film for the opening sequence) and suffered a near-fatal heart attack. Then there's the typhoon that struck the Philippines and destroyed most of the film's sets, putting Coppola (\\"The Godfather\\" trilogy) even further behind schedule. Coppola ended up plowing most of his personal fortune into the film, risking bankruptcy, his marriage and his reputation on a project which was out of control. As he said himself: \\"We made the film like America fought in Vietnam - We had too much money, too much equipment, and little by little we went insane\\". It's astonishing that Coppola could salvage anything remotely coherent from the chaotic circumstances in which \\"Apocalypse Now\\" was made. In fact he produced a masterpiece; an intoxicating, utterly singular audio-visual experience which blows away the timid ambitions of most American war films. Aided by the great editor and sound designer Walter Murch, and the glorious cinematography of Vittorio Storaro, Coppola made \\"Apocalypse Now\\" less of a typical war movie and more of a hallucinogenic trip down the river of a young man's mind and soul.  That young man is Martin Sheen, who plays the introspective Willard to perfection, but his performance is unquestionably eclipsed by some of those around him. In a few short scenes Robert Duvall's Colonel Kilgore seems to sum up everything \\"Apocalypse Now\\" is about; the madness, power and machismo. To see Kilgore standing tall, admiring the waves, while all those around him duck to avoid the flying bullets and explosions, is to witness one of modern cinema's most memorable characterizations. Kilgore is blessed with some of the film's most memorable lines - \\"Charlie don't surf\\", \\"I love the smell of napalm in the morning\\" - and is at the center of 'Apocalypse Now''s greatest sequence. The helicopter attack, accompanied by Wagner's 'The Ride of the Valkyries', is one of the most incredible pieces of filmmaking in history. Spectacular, horrific and undeniably thrilling, the attack is masterfully orchestrated by Coppola and is even more satisfying in these days of CGI and digital fakery. It's a high point from which the film, for a while, fails to recover. <br /> <br/>The rest of the film has an increasingly looming shadow cast over it. Willard and his crew slowly make their way up the river to confront Kurtz, and the anticipation of Brando's appearance grows. Brando turned up late, overweight and had read neither the script nor the source material. To hide his bulk, Coppola shot him in semi-darkness, with the light glinting off his enormous shaved head. It turns Kurtz into mythical figure, and Brando's portrayal suits the character of Kurtz, a man drunk on power, broken by warfare.  In 2001 Coppola produced a director's cut entitled 'Apocalypse Now Redux', adding 49 minutes of deleted footage to his original masterwork. Some of this footage was welcome (More Duvall, more Brando, the Playboy bunnies), while the long, politically motivated French plantation sequence adds little to the film and detracts from the film's narrative. \\"Apocalypse Now\\" was a film made by people out of their minds, with the odds stacked against them, and the film reflected that background - it's what made it so special. \\"Redux\\"' is an attempt to make sense of an insane film by people who have had time to reflect, to mature, and their attempts only manage to dilute some of the original's edge.  Nevertheless, \\"Apocalypse Now\\" is a film that everyone should see in some form, a true masterpiece which reveals new layers and aspects with each repeat viewing. Will we ever see the like of it again? I doubt it. The film is the ultimate apotheosis of 70's filmmaking - a drug-fuelled, self-indulgent, daring piece of work which is so filled with ambition it almost collapses under its own weight. There is no denying the film's raw power and many of the trademark set pieces will never be forgotten or equaled. It's an awesome paradox of a movie; crazy, insightful, overblown and intimate all at once. In it's own unique and magnificent way, \\"Apocalypse Now\\" reflects the madness, intensity and \\"the horror, the horror\\" of warfare.  <br />
B00011F5DK|5.0|I only bought this game because it was recommended to me time and time again. It looked boring and simplistic, but I figured there must be something I wasn't seeing. And there was! B000FBGBPC|3.0|It's typical that most bands end up lagging down to the typical machinations of the recording industry with their sophomore efforts.  As an industry standard, it's sad to watch, and most careers are either make or break.  Bands like Staind propelled to musical heights with their \\"major label sophomore\\" album, and for good reason.  The musicianship went through the roof, and the band stood together and made classic songs.  Now, with the release of Three Days Grace, it seems that another band has instead fallen victim to the sophomore slump.  Regardless of what all the MTV teens will tell you in their own Amazon.com reviews on this record (which I already have problems with the fact that every album seems to get five stars), this effort just doesn't stand up to their debut album, and honestly, it isn't a good sign of things to come. <br /> <br />The first thing most people will flock to is their single, \\"Animal I Have Become\\", which is a rather funny song when you think about it.  In their previous single \\"Just Like You\\", they talked about a duality between not being like the past generation of their fathers and mothers, while at the same time, talking about how they refuse to be like all the other bands out there with their radio singles.  It was the promise of \\"I Hate Everything About You\\" that made the band seem so good and warm and easy to grip onto.  However, they've fallen into cookie cutter fashion by providing exactly what the record company wanted:  a single.  Sadly, the album follows in the same suit, rather than offering up more than maybe two songs worth of advanced musicianship. <br /> <br />As you continue on the record, you'll find songs like \\"Pain\\" and \\"Never Too Late\\", which do nothing better to disprove the failings of this record.  Not only do they follow a by-the-numbers idea of a rock song, but they take the band far away from their emotional and evocative feel on the first album.  Instead, they get even closer to being that little band on TRL that has to entertain all the little kiddies with stories of anger and atypical pieces of lyrical content that can be found on any random CD you pick up from the shelves at Best Buy. <br /> <br />Songs like \\"Riot\\" and \\"Time of Dying\\" are gems on the album, but still, they never reach the same emotional level as previous tracks on their last record like \\"Take Me Under\\" or \\"Wake Up\\".  Still, they hold enough of the good parts of the cookie cutter rock band while offering their own unique style of downbeat and crunch heavy flair to keep you attached.  The drum work, guitar rhythms and some of the slightly off-time signatures, and more over, the inspired lyrics make them true treasures to find embedded into the tracklisting. <br /> <br />Then again, there are flat out weak offerings that turn the disc into a bit of a farce, also.  When you look at songs like the pathetically underwhelming title track \\"One X\\", or even try to submit yourself to the wretched rip-off of \\"Just Like You\\" that they call \\"Gone Forever\\" (at least in the chorus), you have to question whether this band really cares about the music they are writing. <br /> <br />Such a good guitar sound, solid drumming, and unique vocals carried the first album, but only a few times is it ever displayed on this album.  Hopefully, the next effort is better.  No, I'm not going to break down each song for you and rate them, because that's just retarded.  If I wanted to rate a single, then I'd criticize the radio.  Here, I'm speaking about an album, and while \\"It's All Over\\" is a pretty decent song and solid opener for most bands, Three Days Grace can do so much better than what is heard on One X.  We know this, only because they did a better album last time around.  Take precaution in checking out this album, as it'll be for everyone that \\"matters\\" and only mediocre, if not bland, for those true to the ways of rock 'n' roll.

B000005H4X|4.0|This was my introduction to Bu in my college days, and in retrospect it barely scratches the surface. For a follow-up, pick up the eponymous collection on Columbia with Hank Mobley and Donald Byrd. Also, be certain your Blakey collection generously represents, among trumpet players, Clifford Brown, Kenny Dorham, Freddie Hubbard, and Bill Hardman (not to mention Valery Ponomarev, Wynton Marsalis, and Terrence Blanchard). As for saxophonists, Golson, despite his compositional talents, is one of the lesser players to occupy that spot in a Blakey ensemble. Even when it comes to composers, if there's a \\"genius\\" among the Blakey contributors, it's Walter Davis, Jr. \\"Jodie,\\" \\"Ronnie's a Dynamite Lady,\\" \\"Backgammon,\\" \\"Uranus,\\" \\"Gypsy Folk Tales,\\" \\"Scorpio Rises\\"--these are all Davis compositions that Blakey saw fit to record--challenging, adventurous material that places Blakey in the forefront of modern, progressive music, a musicmaker beyond category as opposed to being simply leader of jazz' foremost \\"hard bop\\" ensemble.<br /><br />It's not easy to find, but look for another \\"Moanin'\\" on Laserlight. Recorded live, it features Hardman playing the title song like there was no tomorrow along with a cadenza on \\"Blue Moon\\" that Freddie, who introduced the tune on \\"3 Blind Mice,\\" could have played only in his dreams. Another good introduction to Hardman's trumpet artistry is the Italian LP, \\"Art's Break,\\" on which Art stops the band while Bill plays for half a dozen choruses unaccompanied.<br /><br />That's jazz. That's the inexhaustible world of Art Blakey.

0792839692|4.0|This 1976 science fiction film is best interpreted in a symbolic and allegorical way.  The premise is a future society in which life spans are limited to 30 years, through forced euthanasia, although the plot is too implausible and riddled with inconsistencies to be taken literally.  The symbolism can be read in several ways.  At one level, the film attacks organized religion for keeping people docile with the promise of an imaginary afterlife.  At another, it implies that material comforts reduce the ability to think critically.  But what Logan's run offers primarily is a bizarre vision of the cult of eternal youth evolving into a police state.  There are clear references to a commercial culture that glorifies youth and lives in denial about death.  The world depicted here is at once hedonistic and claustrophobic.  The environment is a kind of shallow, Disneyesque paradise from which there is no hope of escape.  The implicit subtext of the movie, that hedonism is a kind of deathtrap, is well taken.
B000FQJAIW|4.0|For years, fans of the original \\"Star Wars\\" trilogy have been waiting for George Lucas to release the unaltered version of the movies. And we finally get it on DVD, in its original aspect ratio! And, just in case you didn't get the first boxset of the enhanced original \\"Star Wars\\" trilogy, you get the enhanced versions with them! But unfortunately...    George Lucas does NOTHING to make the quality of the UNALTERED versions better.    1. The widescreen is NOT anamorphic (which means the picture will be very narrow on your widescreen TV).  2. The picture, although it's clear, is not digitally remastered.  3. The sound is not enhanced. Dolby Digital 2.0. The sound can be very meshy, and might not be effective if you have surround sound.    George Lucas said he did not intend to release the original versions. It's obvious he wasn't very proud of them. And ONLY just because of mad fan protest, he gives them a quick release, but shows his fans that he doesn't care that much about the original versions.    It's a great product to have if you're a die-hard fan, still. I would only recommend just buying the enhanced version boxset if you're a casual fan.

B00005OWEG|5.0|Director Francis Ford Coppola once said of his epic movie, \\"My film is not about Vietnam...it IS Vietnam.\\"  This can be grossly misinterpreted.  Whether or not you agree with America's actions in the Vietnam War, it is obvious that our soldiers were not as outlandish and insane as they are portrayed to be in \\"Apocalypse Now Redux.\\"  The actions and attitudes of the soldiers of the film aren't accurate in reflecting the real-life men who actually served in the war, but instead reflect the characteristics of the war itself-madness, evil, hate, etc.  So this film, as a matter of fact, is Vietnam, more from a psychological standpoint than a physical one. <br />     Starting with the opening hallucination/dream sequence, complete with napalm explosions and the continuous \\"thwock thwock\\" sound of approaching helicopters, \\"Apocalypse Now Redux\\" dives deep into a dark, unforgettable head-trip of a movie and never resurfaces.   <br />     Captain Willard(Martin Sheen) is ordered to locate Colonel Walter Kurtz(Marlon Brando), who, to put it mildly, has fallen off his rocker.  According to intelligence, Kurtz has gone outside military regulations and formed his own renegade army.  Once he locates Kurtz, Willard's job is to \\"terminate...with extreme prejudice.\\"  The rest of the film, in a nutshell,  chronicles Willard's adventures and interactions with many strange and despicable characters.  As he gets closer and closer to his objective, he becomes more and more obsessed with Kurtz.    <br />     While the content of the movie is violent, there was not as much on-screen bloodshed as I had been led to believe.  Like I said, the film is much more of a psychological metaphor.  Psychological or not, \\"Apocalypse Now Redux\\" truly is an unforgettable viewing experience.  One aspect of the film that really impressed me was the cinematography by Vittorio Storaro, which gave the landscape a lush, yet deadly, image.  None of the actors particularly stuck out, even Robert Duvall's well-known character Kilgore(\\"I love the smell of napalm in the morning...\\") didn't leave much of an impression on me.  Not that the acting was bad, but the film owes more to the story, which is heavily based on Joseph Conrad's famous \\"Heart of Darkness\\", than to its cast.   <br />     Amidst the napalm explosions, \\"Apocalypse Now Redux\\" is one movie that will leave a lasting impression on your mind, for it IS Vietnam, from, of course, a psychological standpoint. <br /> <br />DVD features...Pretty slim.  Only a theatrical trailer, but I have heard that a two-disc version of the film will be released in August.  Besides, the movie's length takes up a majority of the disc.  Sound and picture are both pretty good.              <br />

B00005JP0A|5.0|This is an excellent little satire on getting ahead in business and how we sometimes have to sell our souls in the process.    Or, rather, how we *choose* to sell our souls in the process.    The Devil Wears Prada is about a fresh out of college, would-be journalist (Hathaway) who gets her first job as an assistant for a high-powered fashionista (Streep). She soon learns that nothing about her job is fair or even palatable, but that she's going to have to adapt to it in order to accomplish her dreams of being a serious journalist. However, she eventually has to confront the question \\"is it worth it?\\" as she realizes that the job changes her in the process, and puts her at odds with the people she'd once loved and was loved by.    This is an excellent question, and this film is an excellent examination of that question.    People who've never been in the kind of work environment shown here might not find as much humor in it as I did. What makes it all so funny/painful is how true it all is. I trust that the author of the novel upon which this movie was based must have had a strong real-life experience in a similar situation. While perhaps exaggerated, it's really real.    This is a great film and a good time, and brings up many things worth thinking and talking about. Finally, this review would be remiss if I didn't bring up the incredible display of beauty, here. Anne Hathaway is breathtaking, and she will be one of the great sex symbols of the next several years to come.    Well worth watching.

B00007KWHP|5.0|Hi my people. I am back once again to expound yet another wise and ethereal musical choice worth further investigation. You all will be happy to know that I acquired a smart looking red.white, and blue Seers cap for this holiday season. It was given to me by Chance (my neo-maven guide whom you haven't met yet). So, indeed, I am taking a chance wearing it in the hopes that it will help me make crisp observations about this selection.<br /><br />First off, Fragile is the ultimate high-water mark in the world of progressive rock. How did this come to be? Well certainly Yes, before this, was quite a talented and creative band. But this album represented a quantitative leap from their previous effort and remains a true classic in every sense of the word. But why should this be so? Certainly Rick Wakeman, the advant garde prodigy of keyboard, had alot to do with it. With his effort this band was given polish, nuance and the freedom to explore different uncharted waters of popular music. Like the wooden plane on the cover, the discovery and searching for more aspects of the world (and music) became an over indulgent pleasure. But his competence gave all the other band members the ability to raise their own level of play, and in this selection we have the greatest example of creative interplay ever recorded.  Sound like I'm awed? You better believe I am.<br /><br />There are many musical themes here.  And themes within themes. Repeated, then lost, then reappearing, sometimes changed and then sometimes not.  It is up to the astute listener to really hear how all the individual parts equal the totality of the sound. But this, good friends, is what Seers talk about in their mystical chatrooms. Don't tell Chance I told you. Although spiritual, he can be very vindictive.<br /><br />Each artist on this recording provides thematic glue to bind everything together. Not that they are all on the same page every moment. But the individual forays into what their own instrument can accomplish somehow, magically, all falls into place. It is a puzzle which produces amazing results.<br /><br />We begin with \\"Roundabout\\" which I equate with a dimensional shift in perspective.  Listening closely you can hear how Wakeman introduces the song seguing into Steve Howe's excellent intro. The song moves from that soft passage to driving beat with all contributing equal parts of flair and snippets of incredible nuance to the whole. It then slows down to Jon's soft vocal and then rises dramatically back to the rythmn's driving force. Pay attention to this motif, because Yes uses this plan many times throughout. Just like the cover, Yes's music can travel high to the sky and then swoop down to the ocean and then rise over mountains.<br /><br />Wakeman then gives us a wonderful classical break with \\"Cans and Brahms\\". This selection reveals his mastery of moog and keyboard and, interestingly enough, provides us with a glimpse of the genuine class you can find in this genre.<br /><br />We then have the jaunty \\"We Have Heaven\\" whereby Jon Anderson's vocals really have a field day singing lyrics that, although each has it's own melodic structure, somehow blend together. This key also extends to the music. How each distinct unrelated pattern can blend to make up the whole.<br /><br />\\"South Side of the Sky\\", after the swirling wind intro, provides you with some very fine juxtaposed complimentary riffs from Steve Howe and Chris Squire. And have I yet mentioned Squire to you? What he does with bass guitar in this album is make it a formidable force and a distinct, essential instrument in it's own right. It provides bottom for sure, but then extends into it's own spatial realm and becomes a force equal to the other instruments. The music changes path during midway and after Wakeman provides a dramatic stop with the piano, he is then off offering a new a delicate piano theme. Although about being trapped in a snowstorm, this song coveys amazing range.<br /><br />\\"Five PerCent For Nothing\\" is quite a quizzical short musical piece. Jumpy and erratic - they all throw snippets of musical excursion into the mix and somehow, somehow it all comes together! It boggles the mind!<br /><br />\\"Long Distance Runaround\\" is sheer pleasure. Listen for Squire's dancing bass pattern and listen how Wakeman transposes the main riff with an alternate version in the song. Bruford's drumming on this becomes adventurous and essential. A lyric they include here is \\"Hot colour, melting the anger to stone\\". How can this be? Does it make sense? How can anything melt and become stone? Maybe lava perhaps. But, in Yes language, this is such a great line.<br /><br />We then have Squire's interesting and quavering bass on \\"The Fish\\" and then, another beautiful classical snippet from Wakeman called \\"Mood For a Day\\". The thread that links all these selections together, although being magical, are also fragile indeed.<br /><br />We then come to the gem of the album. Yes, \\"Heart of the Sunrise\\" incorporates and extends all the qualities I've talked about so far. Listen to that beginning. That fast, dual driven riff by Howe and Squire(with fills by Wakeman) are to die for. You then get to the Squire solo starting off with just the most incredible drum fills by Bruford. After this barrage of sound enter Howe again with that wonderful, soft see-saw intro into Jon's vocals. It is beautiful, lilting and an emotional texture and homage to lost love. It swerves, moves upward, into that final awesome crescendo at the end. Everytime I hear this song it just gets better and better.<br /><br />On the remastered version we have a version of \\"America\\" and an early mix of \\"Roundabout\\". Interesting and excellent as they are, they really offer no further insight into the main body of work.<br /><br />People. This album is such great stuff. My enthusiasm never dims. It is a lush, generous recording and, amazing enough, with each listen you will discover more worlds as Fragile did when it was recorded.  The wonder of this album is that you can hear it differently each time you hear it? How? Well, one time I can listen to Squire's bassline. The next, Howe's contribution. And so forth accordingly. Then, to get really creative you could listen to Howe and Squire or Wakeman and Bruford or Jon and Wakeman or Bruford and Squire. Pick out your own permutations. They are all equal value to the sum of the parts and this is what drives Fragile into the exceptional range.<br /><br />Well People. That's it. Got to look for Chance now and get to that Independence Day party. I am wearing that hat and sunglasses as a disguise. I hope my flowing robe and long white beard don't give me away. Do you think it will?<br /><br />Ah well. To all --a wonderful and exciting holiday. Let us all celebrate the freedom of our minds as well. Blessings - your Metamorphol short musical piece. Jumpy and erratic - they all throw snippets of musical excursion into the mix and somehow, somehow it all comes together! It boggles the mind! <br />\\"Long Distance Runaround\\" is sheer pleasure. 1592400876|4.0|A neighbor of mine highly recommended this book to me.  I am not sure of her background, but she knew I had a background in grammar, so she thought I would like it.  However, I had since spoken with two friends of mine who are both smarter than I (and don't have a background in grammar).  Both told me that they didn't like the book as they found it insulting. <br /> <br />In both cases, they read the book to learn more about punctuation but felt that the author was insulting them for not being as good at punctuation as she.  In reading the book, I can see where this comes from, but that is not the author's purpose.  The author is showing us proper punctuation, but she is also trying to get us to set our collective foot down.  I see what she means.  At the courtroom in a nearby town, a door in the back states \\"Employee's Only.\\"  I don't exactly know what they mean by that, but the sight of the unneeded apostrophe bothers me.  What are we coming to? <br /> <br />Although there is much to learn here about punctuation, the book is intended more for a reminder rather than a primer.  If any reader has trouble with the comma and its ilk, then this is probably not the best book.  For both the skilled and unskilled, take a close look at the book.  As it was originally written in England, it may very well be geared towards British English.  There are differences in the punctuation used on both sides of the ocean, so be wary.

078324228X|3.0|This is an entertaining movie, albeit historically inaccurate at times.  For example, there is a scene in the movie where Carter is \\"robbed\\" by a decision where he lost to Joey Giardello, the middleweight champion.  This was a real cheap shot at Giardello, who won the fight on all three cards, in Philadelphia. Like most big punchers, Carter tired in the later rounds, with the champion hurting him with left hooks in the last three rounds.                                                          <br />As boxing historian Jack Newfield pointed out, the only person who believes Carter won that fight is Norman Jewison, the movie's producer. In today's world, the most prominent historians are filmmakers; it would be helpful if they tried to be more accurate.

0553293397|4.0|Elijah Baley solves another case with his logical yet unreasonable partner, R Daneel Olivaw. This time it is not within the steel caves of New York City, but in the open plains of the sparsely populated Solaria. A world that has reached the epitome of technological paradise.<br /><br />Though, the book is not necessarily well written as a detective piece. The murderer is somewhat obvious, and the investigation can at times be dull. What is interesting is this new world Asimov created. A world so wrapped up with the companionship of their advanced robots, that people shudder at the thought of seeing another person in the flesh. Some people will faint at the sight. Some people will stay a good twenty feet away from a man. Some people will do worse. They are enslaved to the robots for their livelihood, their protection, and they are even mothered by the robots after birth.<br /><br />It turns out that Earth is exactly the same in many ways. But instead of being isolated from individuals, Earth is isolated by other cities, other planets, other ventures. Baley can barely last five minutes in the Solarian sun without fainting himself. Whereas Solaria's wealthy estates ran only by robots cause people to fear anyone one person, Earth's primitively walled in cities cause people to fear manifest destiny.<br /><br />PS: There was a certian individual who claimed that the nudity exhibited in this novel should have been cesnored.  I am in complete disagreement in the first case because I do not believe in censorship.  Despite this, I do not believe that there is anything in this book to censor.  The only line that makes desciption of the female form is as followed, \\"Gladia looked down at her nudity in surprise and said, 'Well of course'\\" (61).  Not a single word is used to illustrate a nude body other than the word \\"nudity\\" itself.  Everything is left to the imagination and is very tasteful.  I would say the taboo of nudity in this novel, though it is not portrayed in explicit detail, is what makes this book intriguing as oppose to revolting.icit detail, is what makes this book intriguing as oppose to revolting.

B000GCFO0I|5.0|First off I have quite a background on silent hill since I have played all but one of the American games released. So I have what you can say a better understanding of what to expect than I person whose going to see Silent Hill because of an captivating trailer or a friends opinion.  Now, in every Silent Hill you play as a character that is drawn to the town of Silent Hill through a plot. In this case you look through the eyes of Rose Da Silva searching for an answer for her child's illness. So the movie plays out as Rose searching for Silent Hill and is determined to go there to hopefully find some answers. When she arrives there she meets characters, solves simple puzzles of leading one clue onto the next until finally finding her daughter. Of course along the way she gets to meet a bunch of memorable badies from throughout the entire Silent Hill series of video games.  Now it's quite easy to simply throw a video game into a movie blender and puree on low for 127 minutes. But what comes out can be quite disappointing, which is a pretty high reputation for video game to movie conversions.  Instead Silent Hill is seemingly integrated from its origins and is plotted out step by step literally immersing you into a silent hill game on autopilot. You get the action, puzzles, creepiness, the mysteriousness, the music, the atmosphere, the immersion; you get Silent Hill THE MOVIE. (Intense!) . However this takes me to a review I read previously and enlightens me how carelessly someone has overlooked the movie with shallow expectations. This goes back to that person mentioning that Christopher DaSilva as a character deemed pretty incoherent or pointless. Sure at first glance he is quickly recorded bickering throughout the movie with the cop here and there. But If you take a closer look at his role, he is actually the entity that the visually shows you the separation between Silent Hill and the \\"Real world.\\" Just a small example to look at the whole picture.  So whether or not you're still deciding to watch Silent Hill, I think it's worth the experience, and although you may or may not like it, this movie will ultimately give you the definition of what Silent Hill really is!
